studyLessons.title: Honoring God

studySections.content:
1 Corinthians 6:18-20 Amplified Bible (AMP)

18 Run away from sexual immorality [in any form, whether thought or behavior, whether visual or written]. Every other sin that a man commits is outside the body, but the one who is sexually immoral sins against his own body. 19 Do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit who is within you, whom you have [received as a gift] from God, and that you are not your own [property]? 20 You were bought with a price [you were actually purchased with the precious blood of Jesus and made His own]. So then, honor and glorify God with your body.

It’s helpful to review from time to time exactly why we are to live differently from the rest of the world. As Christians, particularly Christian men because we are visual, everything that is done with our body impacts God; the things we look at, the things we listen to, the things we act on and the things we think about. God’s Spirit resides in every follower of Jesus Christ, and so everything that we do should be in respect to God. 

Honoring God by what we do with our body is a form of spiritual worship (Romans 12:1-2). It shows God that we respect Him and our bodies, which are made in His image. Our body is literally a temple of the Holy Spirit of God. This temple is owned by God, and leased back to us for use to glorify God. If we use it to dishonor God sexually, it is sinning “against the body.” The consequences of sinning against one’s own body are not specified in this passage, but Ted Roberts tells us we are actually causing our own "brain damage" through lust, missed opportunities to serve God and a separation in our relationship with God. 

“So then, honor and glorify God with your body ” (verse 20). The benefits of honoring God with our bodies are awesome. 
"But the Holy Spirit produces this kind of fruit in our lives: love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, 23 gentleness, and self-control." (Galatians 5:22-23 NLT). 
I encourage you to believe that these results are desirable and worth the effort of resisting the temptations of sin.

studyLessons.author: Joe Henika

studyLessons.title: Accountability (displays at the end of every lesson)

studySections.content: These questions are sent to your accountability partner's email address and your email address (if you have accountability configured).
Have you indulged in sexual sin since you last sent an accountability email?
If so, in what ways without being explicit?  What "boundaries" did you cross?
How do you feel?  Any concerns or lack of peace that indicate you should take care of something with the Lord?
In what ways have you connected with the Lord since the previous lesson?
